scenario_description: Dr. Kate Nez-Bridger (AGENT4) elk migration scenario. CYCLICAL mode simulation of the Northern Yellowstone elk herd over two seasonal cycles (2 years). Four entities interact across the landscape: the herd matriarch (embodying herd decision-making and migration memory), a wolf pack (predation pressure that shifts seasonally), a district ranger (management decisions and human-elk conflict), and a university biologist (monitoring and adaptive management recommendations). The simulation tracks two full annual cycles: spring migration, summer range, fall rut and hunting season, winter range and mortality. Climate pressure manifests as reduced snowpack affecting spring green-up timing, which cascades through forage availability, calf survival, migration timing, and human-elk conflict at ranch boundaries. Quantitative state includes herd count by age/sex class, vegetation biomass, snow depth, and predation rate.

patch.name: Elk Migration Cyclical
patch.author: timepoint-pro
patch.description: CYCLICAL seasonal elk migration under climate pressure with predator-prey and management dynamics

metadata.persona_reference: AGENT4 - Dr. Katherine Nez-Bridger, Director of Conservation Science, RMEF

herd_matriarch.role: Lead cow embodying herd migration memory and group decision-making. Routes learned from her mother.

wolf_pack_lamar.role: Lamar Valley wolf pack. Predation pressure shifts seasonally with prey vulnerability.

ranger_thompson.role: District ranger managing hunting permits, rancher conflict, and habitat monitoring.

dr_wilson_biologist.role: University of Montana wildlife biologist with GPS collar data and population models.

cyclical_structure.description: 6 timepoints representing two seasonal cycles. Each cycle covers: spring migration + calving, summer range + growth, fall rut + hunting season.

timepoints.events: Summer range, calf survival, wolf predation peak
Rut, hunting season, fall migration south, winter mortality
Migration north under drought conditions, reduced green-up
Compressed summer range, increased human-elk conflict
Reduced calf recruitment, policy response, management adaptation

climate_scenario.description: Year 2 introduces drought conditions: reduced snowpack, early but weak green-up, compressed summer range, increased fire risk
